prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: MM2-H2D+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: H2D+ (1_11-1_10), N2H+(4-3), DCO+(5-4) and continuum. Single pointing centered on MM2.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The correlator setup is chosen to cover our main target line, H2D+(1_1,0-1_1,1), with sufficient spectral resolution to study the line profile. As also discussed above (see Sensitivity section), the H2D+ line may be as narrow as ~0.5 km/s (~thermal linewidth for T~17 K), which dictates the choice of ~0.1 km/s spectral resolution. (Our correlator setup includes x4 spectral averaging to reduce the data rate.) As noted in the Sensitivity section, if the line is weaker than expected, we can smooth both spatially and spectrally to improve the S/N.
Our correlator setup is also chosen to observe two additional lines of interest "for free": N2H+(4-3) and DCO+(5-4). We expect the N2H+ line to be quite narrow (<2.5 km/s, and potentially <1 km/s; Fontani et al. 2006, A&A, 460, 709), with features at the level of ~0.1 km/s, and so request 0.05 km/s spectral resolution (employing x2 spectral averaging to reduce the data rate with minimal effect on the spectral resolution). If necessary, we will bin the N2H+ data to improve the S/N. For DCO+, the observed linewidths for a sample of dense cores observed in DCO+(4-3) by Miettinen et al. (2012, A&A, 538, A137) are typically ~0.5 km/s, so we request 0.117 km/s spectral resolution to have >4 resolution elements across the line (if DCO+ is detected, see above).
We use an FDM rather than TDM continuum window so that we can more effectively remove line contamination, in particular for the MM1 hot core (Cyganowski et al. 2011, ApJ, 729, 124, Cyganowski et al. 2014, ApJL, 796, 2). We have selected a spectral averaging factor of 2 to reduce the data rate. The resulting spectral resolution (~0.95 km/s) is comparable to that of our SMA data; based on the SMA data, we expect ~1 km/s resolution to be sufficient to detect and identify line emission, and so decontaminate the continuum. Observing in FDM mode with ~1 km/s resolution may also allow the study of additional lines (e.g. towards MM1), increasing the scientific and archival value of the dataset.

Our goal is to detect H2D+ line emission from MM2, so we wish to match our requested synthesized beamsize to the expected size of the H2D+ emitting region. The MM2 core is slightly resolved in our highest-resolution SMA continuum image (lambda=1.3 mm, beam=0.574" x 0.370"). The deconvolved size of MM2, as measured from our SMA continuum images, ranges from ~0.45" to ~ 1.2" in our highest/lowest resolution SMA data. (Quoted sizescales are the geometric mean of the deconvolved source size, measured from 2D Gaussian fitting in the image plane.) Our highest (0.46") and lowest (2.4") resolution SMA data were taken with the same 1.3 mm tuning, so the measured continuum flux densities can be compared directly (e.g. without the need to scale by a spectral index). The high-resolution image recovers ~ 44% of the flux, indicating that a significant amount of mass is extended on ~ arcsecond scales. However, this more extended structure also has a lower (mean) density (~10^7 cm^-3, Cyganowski et al. 2011, ApJ, 729, 124). Since H2D+ traces very dense, depleted gas (see Science Case), we expect the size of the H2D+ emitting region to be comparable to the size of the very dense core marginally resolved in our highest-resolution SMA data, e.g. ~0.45". We therefore request an angular resolution of 0.5" to provide a good match to the size of the H2D+ emitting region--and so avoid beam dilution--while achieving sufficient brightness temperature sensitivity. The largest angular scale is at most 5" (based on our SMA imaging), which is recoverable in the single configuration that can deliver the requested resolution.
The requested resolution is also necessary to fully isolate emission from MM2 from possible emission from other (proto)cluster members (both known sources and fainter neighbors that may be newly-detected by ALMA). At a distance of 3.4 kpc, the beam corresponds to ~1700 AU, which is comfortably below the typical size scale of separation between massive protostars (~5,000-10,000 AU).
A single pointing, centered on MM2, covers the area of interest. The hot core MM1, ~7" from MM2 (Science Case, Fig. 1), lies approximately at the 50% power point of the primary beam, sufficient for high S/N (continuum) imaging. (Due to MM1's very different physical properties and so very different chemistry, we do not expect H2D+ or N2H+ emission from MM1).

Our sensitivity requirement is based on detecting H2D+(1_1,0-1_1,1) emission at the 3 sigma level in a 0.1 km/s resolution element, for our most pessimistic plausible estimate of the H2D+ line strength for the MM2 core. The considerations and assumptions that go into estimating the H2D+ line strength are discussed in detail in the Science Case; in summary, our most pessimistic plausible case for MM2 is T_MB(H2D+)~0.9 K, for T=17 K, X(H2D+)~10^-12, ortho/para-H2D+(T=17 K)~0.1, and delta_v=0.5 km/s~the thermal linewidth (the best-fit temperature for MM2 is ~17-19 K, see Science Case).
For this most pessimistic plausible case, the estimated H2D+ brightness temperature T_MB(H2D+)~0.9 K, for a linewidth of delta_v=0.5 km/s ~ the thermal linewidth for T=17 K. Thus, we request a 1 sigma rms of 0.3 K per 0.1 km/s resolution element (~8.5 mJy/beam for our 0.5" beam). We expect the size of the H2D+ emitting region to be well-matched to the 0.5" beam (see Imaging section), but note that if necessary we can smooth both spatially and spectrally to improve the S/N (as in Friesen et al. 2014, ApJ, 797, 27, who report the first interferometric detection of H2D+ with ALMA in Cycle 0). As discussed in the Science Case, however, it is more likely that the H2D+ line will be stronger than our most-pessimistic case, by a factor of 5 or more. We also note that the integrated S/N of the H2D+ line will be higher than our requested 3 sigma per spectral resolution element. We request 0.1 km/s spectral resolution (and use this bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation) to provide a sufficient number of resolution elements across the H2D+ line (>=5) to allow study of the line profile.
The other lines in our correlator setup, N2H+(4-3) and DCO+(5-4), represent science "for free" (see Science Case); our sensitivity requirement is driven by H2D+, as discussed above. The corresponding 1 sigma sensitivity for N2H+(4-3) is 0.33 K per 0.05 km/s resolution element (~9.4 mJy/beam for our 0.5" beam). As discussed in the Science Case, whether or not we detect N2H+ will constrain the degree of N2 freezeout, and provide a test of astrochemical models under extreme physical conditions. Similarly, we include DCO+ in our correlator setup to obtain an additional constraint (abundance, or abundance limit) on astrochemistry in extreme conditions. Based on our UCL-CHEM astrochemical modeling (described in the Science Case), we do not expect DCO+ to be detectable in MM2 (predicted DCO+ abundance <10^-15): the 1 sigma sensitivity is 0.13 K per 0.117 km/s resolution element (~3.5 mJy/beam for our 0.5" beam).
Our correlator setup will also provide an exquisitely sensitive continuum image of MM2. The continuum rms from the OT, for the aggregate bandwidth, is 62 uJy/beam. The lines are expected to be narrow (see above and Correlator configuration section, below), so the aggregate bandwidth is a reasonable approximation of the usable continuum bandwidth.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Core accretion models of high-mass star formation require the existence of gravitationally bound massive starless cores, but robust observational examples of such objects have proven elusive. We have identified an excellent candidate for a massive prestellar core in the course of our extensive studies of GLIMPSE Extended Green Objects (EGOs): G11.92-0.61-MM2. Separated by ~7" from the nearby MM1 hot core, MM2 is a strong dust continuum source, but devoid of star formation indicators. In contrast to MM1, MM2 has no masers, no cm continuum, and, remarkably, no line emission in SMA (sub)mm observations covering ~24 GHz of bandwidth. The combined physical properties of MM2, inferred from its (sub)mm continuum emission, are extreme: T~17-19 K and M>30 Msun within a radius<1000 AU, corresponding to N(H2)>10^25 cm^-2 and n(H2)>10^9 cm^-3. We propose deep ALMA observations of MM2 in H2D+, the best tracer of extremely dense, depleted gas in low-mass starless cores. Our goals are to constrain the boundedness and stability of MM2, and to test the hypothesis that MM2 is, physically and chemically, a "scaled-up" analog of a low-mass prestellar core.
